entry.title: Rights - Chocolate with a Purpose - 70% Aji

link.title: Rights - Chocolate with a Purpose - 70% Aji

entry.content:
Rights is the brand whose mission (and marketing strategy) is to employ people with disabilities. Since my last experiences with this brand, the box design has evolved: from festive colors to a more refined image.

The chocolate itself hasn’t changed. Woody and elegant, it is lightly sweetened by panela. The added chili (ají) is not very strong and mostly stays in the background, bringing a pleasant warming touch.

entry.title: Salapi - 70% - Harvest 2025
entry.content:
On the box, Salapi specifies the origin of the 2025 harvest: 56% from Los Rios, 44% from the Galapagos.

This chocolate is gentle and fruity. You can pick out notes of caramel, dried apricot, and melon, with a smooth, controlled texture that melts calmly in the mouth.

A fine and pleasant experience.

entry.title: Kallari - Sacha - 71% Hampik Ushay with Ginger

link.title: Kallari - Sacha - 71% Hampik Ushay with Ginger

entry.content:
Kallari’s cacao is, as always, very gentle. Here it is accompanied by candied ginger pieces and ginger essence present in the chocolate itself. The result is a calm, composed chocolate that doesn’t aim to overwhelm with intense or singular flavors. It is rather a small, fragrant, and pleasant sweetness.

entry.title: Muyus - Otavalo - 60% Passion Fruit
entry.content:
In Otavalo, north of Quito, the Muyus café sells coffee and chocolate. They produce their own bars, though the small print reveals the bar was made by Huma — a collaboration.

This chocolate is a refined candy: small passion fruit pieces strongly punctuate the experience, with the always-winning cocoa-passion combination. It’s a bright, comforting chocolate. Of course, it’s harder to assess the cacao’s finesse itself beyond its round, warm character.

A lovely experience, a treat that stands out.

entry.title: Lua - 85% Ancestral Ecuadorian Cocoa
entry.content:
Another chocolate from Lua, all in little touches, as if painted by a pointillist artist. Very gentle — give it time to reveal itself, and the delicate flavor touches emerge one by one.

Opening with wood and bark, it evolves toward peppermint, honey, and finishes with a surprising hint of cola.

I repeat: it’s very, very gentle. But by letting the velvety squares melt slowly you’ll find fine subtleties.

entry.title: Conexion - 75% Fine Cacao - Los Rios
entry.content:
Fruity and floral, as the purple box of this Conexion chocolate states. It’s true: a light mix of bitterness and acidity recalls grapefruit, rounded by the sweetness of red grapes and powerful fermentation-derived notes.

All of this sits in a crunchy yet smooth texture — a success that confirms Conexion’s steady quality.

entry.title: Napo Cultural Center - Yasuni Pure Bar

link.title: Napo Cultural Center - Yasuni Pure Bar

entry.content:
I found this bar in the souvenir shop of the Napo Cultural Center, located in Yasuni National Park, within the Kichwa Añangu community deep in the Ecuadorian Amazon. In a thatched hut, tucked among beautiful handmade jewelry by indigenous women, a small foil-wrapped package.

At opening, the aroma is striking—powerful fruity notes. In the mouth, you need to wait: this chocolate is very firm, low in cocoa butter, and does not melt quickly. Perhaps by design: it survived several days in the jungle heat.

The flavor takes time to develop but is powerful, pure, almost wild, conveying the depth of Yasuni cacao with notes of cinnamon and apricot. There are also some solid cacao fragments adding a crunchy texture.

The purest chocolate from the Amazon.

entry.title: Chicao - 100% - Fine Aroma Cocoa
entry.content:
Green mint, fir, lemon, bread and butter. The tasting of this 100% chocolate goes through different stages as you let it melt in the mouth or as you eat several pieces. It’s a pleasant chocolate, not bitter at all; on the contrary, it is rich, satisfying, and is enjoyed as you discover its nuances.

Re-reading the description of the Chicao 70% from January 2022, or tasting the two bars one after the other, shows how much sugar changes the notes cocoa plays in a chocolate bar.

entry.title: Minka - Raw - 77% Plain
entry.content:
After trying all the flavor combinations from Minka Raw, it was perhaps time to taste the pure chocolate version.

It hits from the first second: the tasting begins with a refreshing punch, slightly mentholated, a bit eucalyptus-like, which surprises for a pure cocoa product. This aspect stretches across much of the experience. In support rather than front and center, there is a faint hazelnut note and a woody roundness that leans toward a light coffee bitterness if you let the square melt slowly.

As I build experience with Ecuadorian cacao, the diversity and depth of flavors no longer surprise me. Yet with every new bar I’m still amazed by the variety Minka delivers. Minka is an artisan of that diversity.

entry.title: Huma - Identidad Collection - 60% - Choco Chapo
entry.content:
This is not meant to be a flavored chocolate per se. However, the ingredients list includes some machica (toasted barley flour) and cedrón (verbena).

The product is gentle and rich, evoking vanilla chestnut cream both in taste and texture. The toasted barley brings cereal notes, while the verbena adds a subtle fresh lift.

It’s a pleasant, fine, and original chocolate in Huma’s tradition of excellence.

P.S. The tablet packaging, with Tigua mask artwork, deserves a mention on its own!
